body: LGTM, thanks!
@ijuma @harshach @junrao Do you by any chance have time to review this PR? Thank you...
@ijuma Tried to find the discussion. Feel free to point me to it if I overlooked it. Just out of curiosity, what is the alternative to MiniKDC?
@sruehl Can you help me understand why an InterruptException be thrown instead of caught and logged and then the selector closed.

@granthenke The discussion was offline, I closed the PR to make sure it wasn't merged before I had a chance to resubmit. The reasoning is that the MiniKdc library is a single non-test class (the one I copied in this PR in fact) and it's not worth adding a new dependency for that. I need to take a closer look before I make up my own mind.
Makes sense! Thanks for the info @ijuma
@ijuma Another thing to consider, minikdc is also responsible for [KAFKA-2866](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2866), so I would be happy to get rid of it if we have other options.
Yes, I remember :)
@junrao Thanks a lot for the review and comments. I updated the patch using muted partitions. Can you take another look? Thanks.

@ymatsuda @gwenshap @miguno for reviews. It adds the quickstart / configs / developer guide sections for Kafka Streams.

Some related changes:
1. fix indents in the build.gradle file.
2. remove Consumer configs "offset.auto.reset" from StreamsConfig.

I agree we want it gone.

Can you add a note to the docs (in the "deprecated" section) to the effect of: "0.7 KafkaMigrationTool is no longer packaged with Kafka, if you need to migrate from 0.7 to 0.10.0, please migrate to 0.8 first and then follow the documented upgrade process to upgrade from 0.8 to 0.10.0"
?

@gwenshap @granders Simple addition to existing tests to make sure Connect works with all security settings. Not sure if we actually want to include all the variants -- 1 secure version might be enough.
Oh, also, this could actually be double committed if we want -- it cherry-picks cleanly.

I don't have a strong opinion about all the variants.

Do we have a branch-builder test that passed?
@granthenke @SinghAsDev Thanks for your reply. It's better to keep the current logic, and I will close this JIRA as 'Not a Problem'.
@gwenshap Good point on the docs. Thanks for the suggested text, I pretty much copy and pasted it exactly.
@auradkar : In 0.9.0, ProducerRequest.handleError() has the same problem and needs to be fixed. In trunk, we have switched to the java ProducerRequest and thus don't have this issue.
Is it relatively simple to add a test for the new behavior? I think this change might also solve [KAFKA-3468](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3468).

Thank you for the patch!
LGTM
LGTM
@gwenshap Unit tests passed locally.
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.0.
Seems correct. I think the default value is used to create samples. In this case, the Min function would have reported an incorrect value right? Can you write a test case to prove correctness now?
Yes I think it would have. I'll see if there's a relevant max test to keep things similar, or if not I'll write one for both.
LGTM. We can iterate on the contents / formatting later.

The Jenkins failure was `testHighConcurrencyModificationOfResourceAcls`, but it seems irrelevant to this PR. Anyway, I'll rebase this PR to trigger Jenkins test again.

```
kafka.security.auth.SimpleAclAuthorizerTest > testHighConcurrencyModificationOfResourceAcls FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: Should support many concurrent calls failed with exception(s) ArrayBuffer(java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Failed to update ACLs for Topic:test after trying a maximum of 10 times)
        at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
        at org.junit.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:41)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$.assertConcurrent(TestUtils.scala:1122)
        at 
```
If you want a single non-plaintext security protocol, you could go for SASL_SSL as that exercises both SASL and SSL (although it doesn't exercise SSL client authentication).
LGTM, thanks!

I updated `testOldDataHasNoEffect` to include Min, along with a couple other SampledStats. The updated test fails if ran against trunk. I can make a new test if desired, but the flow would be the exact same - the only way initialValue is ever exposed is by measuring a SampledStat with an old Sample that has been reset. If you just measure a new SampledStat without ever calling record, a Sample is never created and initialValue never comes into play. That might be an argument for using initialValue as the default starting value in the implementation of combine, but that seemed like a more substantial (but functionally equivalent) change.

At this time, the failure is the following.

```
kafka.server.OffsetCommitTest > testNonExistingTopicOffsetCommit FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: expected:<0> but was:<16>
        at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
        at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:834)
        at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:645)
        at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:631)
        at kafka.server.OffsetCommitTest.testNonExistingTopicOffsetCommit(OffsetCommitTest.scala:308)
```
I rebased again to retrigger Jenkins test.

Thanks for the contribution. Since you have only changed documentation, don't worry about the failures. @granthenke, looks like the new Authorizer test fails transiently. Can you please file a JIRA and take a look?
Thanks for the PR. It's not clear to me if this should be a warning at the broker level as it doesn't necessarily indicate that there's something wrong. Let's hear what others think though.
@becketqin : Thanks for the patch. The main logic and the tests make a lot of sense to me now. LTGM
I see. Thank you, @ijuma .
Review by @junrao
Review by @guozhangwang please.

I commented on the jira, but adding here too:

> I think the goal of sampling topic data could be done without adding another parameter to Mirrormaker, and without depending on having many partitions. I linked [KAFKA-2670](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3472) which talks about adding a sampling rate to Mirrormaker. The discussion mentions using an interceptor to implement custom sampling. Would that work for your use case?

Started a system tests run as `MiniKdc` is also used by system tests:

https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/396/console
This was mentioned in #1138
Thanks @granthenke. Were you able to reproduce the transient failure before this PR, but no longer after the PR?

I am not able to reproduce the failure locally on my machine. I looked up the failure on Jenkins ([here](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/3085/testReport/junit/kafka.security.auth/SimpleAclAuthorizerTest/testHighConcurrencyModificationOfResourceAcls/)) and the failure is due to too many retries. I suspect this is occurring because of the load on the Jenkins machine. I think lowering the number of concurrent request from 100 to 50 should help prevent this while still maintaining the validity of the test. If we still see issues after this I will definitely look into it deeper.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
Tests passed locally, Jenkins failure is in the streams code, which is unrelated.
OK, LGTM then. Even though this is not guaranteed to fix it, it should improve things (in the worst case, it will remain the same).
LGTM except a few very minor comments.
LGTM.
LGTM. Thanks for the docs update @hachikuji
@granders does the PR look OK to you now?
Minor comments, looks good otherwise.
LGTM! Just a minor comment/ question.
Looks good, a minor comment.
@guozhangwang Addressed the review comments. I wasn't aware that we group java.\* imports after other imports. Interesting, in my experience I've seen the opposite (java.\* imports first).
@granders one more for you to take a look at.

@ijuma There are some discrepancies, yes. But the general idea is to group all kafka.\* imports, and all o.a.kafka.\* imports, and all common java / scala imports along with external dependencies like jackson / log4j.
Merged to trunk and 0.10.0.

```
#
# A fatal error has been detected by the Java Runtime Environment:
#
#  SIGSEGV (0xb) at pc=0x000000011ee99c2a, pid=795, tid=27143
#
# JRE version: Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (8.0_40-b27) (build 1.8.0_40-b27)
# Java VM: Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (25.40-b25 mixed mode bsd-amd64 compressed oops)
# Problematic frame:
# C  [librocksdbjni8364075677477484103..jnilib+0xb9c2a]  _ZN7rocksdb18WriteBatchInternal11SetSequenceEPNS_10WriteBatchEy+0xa
#
```
How does this impact performance?

@jkreps We used an older version of RocksDB(3.10) while doing the experiment, and disabling batch writes does not incur much performance degradation as @ymatsuda observes. We will upgrade to the latest 4.2 version and see if the issue is already fixed.
So far, I was unable to reproduce this with 4.1.
@SinghAsDev Thanks for the update! My primary comment is that you can safely remove all references to security_protocol in the service and the test
LGTM
LGTM
@ijuma would you be interested in reviewing this pull request?
Hi, Let me know if I have to modify in some way :-)

Thanks for the PR. I think we need to document in the code the reasoning for the proposed strategy where most fields are protected by synchronization but a couple are not.

It would also be interesting to know if the consumer also suffers from similar bottlenecks and, if so, whether these change fix that case too.

What are your thoughts @guozhangwang @ewencp? For reference, I quote from the JIRA the relevant figures:

"Due to sync on the single producer, MM in a setup with 32 consumer threads could not send more than 
358k msg/sec hence not being able to saturate the NIC."

"After applying the patch, MM could copy the entire data (447k msg/sec) with no lagging. The bytes-in rate was 183m per sec. We have not tried it yet with an input rate large enough to saturate a 10G NIC and we might discover other bottlenecks when doing so."
Also, it would be good to verify that changing `topics` to a Concurrent implementation doesn't slow down the case where there are less threads.
LGTM, cc @gwenshap
Minor comments, looks good otherwise.
Since this is not the full fix for KAFKA-3177, let's either file a new issue or make sure it remains open after we merge this.

Fixed `minikdc.py` and started another system tests build:

https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/397/

fyi, with this change we got around 1M msg/s (varies on different setup), which is still not high enough to saturate the NIC but still a non-negligible improvement.

we could not identify an obvious bottleneck after this point. the time consuming operations seems to be synchronization on free and incomplete, as well as synchronization on partition dequeue.

I think its great to see performance optimizations like this, but agreed with @ijuma that this definitely needs documentation about the approach and reasoning (and probably a reference to the relevant JIRA). The synchronized approach is clearly simpler to reason about and without any notes in the code it'd be really easy to revert important changes here. (Ideally we'd also have tests that could detect performance regression here. We don't have real support for this in the system tests yet, but this is a pretty specific scenario we'd need to test -- very large # of threads utilizing a single producer.)
cc @gwenshap @ewencp
@gwenshap @ewencp Ping for review

Thanks for the PR @granthenke. I think it would be good to explain a bit more how this hooks into the build. Is it just a command that can be run explicitly, but it doesn't change anything else otherwise (i.e. no slowdown in compilation or test execution speed)? Or does it instrument things by default?

@ijuma This just adds optional tasks to the build to generate the report output. It should not affect the existing build workflow. 

I didn't make it part of the default build for a few reasons:
- this is just an initial patch to have basic coverage reports, more polish may be needed
- instrumentation and testing can add a lot of time to the build
- the report is generally not needed on every build

Eventually we may want to incorporate it and coverage checks into the standard build, but for now I wanted the basic ability to report coverage.

@granthenke Isn't the test simply incorrect since it's asserting something that isn't always true? It seems like its valid to sometimes see an exception as we do here unless we use infinite retries on the `SimpleAclAuthorizers` instance. We don't make any intermediate assertions as far as I can tell, so wouldn't simply adjusting the # of retries result in effectively the same test? Alternatively, catching the specific type of exception `IllegalStateException`, but make sure any other exception is considered a failure (e.g., I guess this would possibly catch something like a `ConcurrentModificationException`).

@ewencp This test was written before the retires code was suggested. It was written validate the state of the acls is correct under high concurrency. We could catch the exception and pass the test, though thats would skip validating the state. Ideally the retry limit would never be reached, especially in real world use.  It was suggested as a safe guard just in case.

Sure. I am about to submit a new PR with documentation.

About concerns of ConcurrentHashMap's read performance, I did a quick test with a single consumer and both approaches gave about 194 Msg/s. Although the experiment was performed only once and number varied over time, it suggests that ConcurrentHashMap's read latency is negligible compared to the overall latency of invoking producer.send

Still if that is a concern we have the option of making topics volatile and replace the reference with a new updated HashMap but i don't see evidence that this would be necessary.

Grant, thanks for restarting this. Code coverage is a useful tool to make sure new patches are coming with proper unit tests. However, it will be hard to say so without some sort of a baseline number. Having a consolidated report, for scala and java code, can give us a reference number. In parent JIRA that is what I tried to achieve. Many projects are already taking advantage of sonarqube, https://analysis.apache.org/. It will be nice to have Kafka take advantage of it as well.
Oh, finally. It passes the Jenkins.

@granthenke Ok, I'm fine committing this to reduce the current set of exceptions, but this still seems weird to me. Given the current code, the comment on `SimpleAclAuthorizer.maxUpdateRetries` isn't really accurate either, is it? You can definitely hit contention for the resource's zk nodes and an exception _should_ be expected under high enough contention. I agree this should be rare in practice and ACL changes really shouldn't be made that quickly, but certainly not impossible.

More generally my question is now: what exactly are we trying to test with this particular unit test? That there aren't any concurrency bugs? Or that arbitrary interleavings of ACL operations still result in the same output? I get that the test makes sense if you have infinite retries, but it seems like what it is testing necessarily has to change if infinite retries were removed.

@SinghAsDev Yes, those features could definitely be useful. I left that out of the scope of this patch ([KAFKA-3451](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3451)) and it still can be done under the parent patch [KAFKA-1722](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-1722). Since that looked to be a longer discussion, this gets some functionality now. 

Please feel free to drive that addition after this patch.

@ewencp The goal of the test is to validate that arbitrary interleaving of ACL operations (due to high concurrency) still result in correct output. Before the patch, ACLs would be dropped and state was lost. The patch aimed to fix and test that. 

Should I make the maxUpdateRetries changeable so that I can validate it with infinite retries? Otherwise I am not sure I can control or pick a good number.

Yea, that is what I meant, just wanted to provide the bigger picture here. @ijuma I think having a separate task will make sure people don't have to unnecessarily wait for coverage reports and coverage reports builds can run the required task.
Thanks for clarifying Grant. My preference is definitely for a separate task, so that's good.

@benstopford Thoughts on this?

I have not been able to verify completely due to setup issues in my environment. But will work on running all the tests to validate the change.
Cc @granders
Thanks @ijuma. Thats who I meant. :)
@granders done! Looks ok now?

This failure looks new to me @hachikuji @ijuma 

```
kafka.api.SslConsumerTest.testListTopics: java.lang.AssertionError: expected:<5> but was:<6>
```

Did you see this one before?
@hachikuji There is some un-addressed comments from @ijuma , otherwise LGTM.

@SinghAsDev LGTM

@gwenshap Mind taking a final look?
Unit test passed locally. LGTM and merge to trunk and 0.10.0.
@guozhangwang Haven't seen that before. I opened a JIRA: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3484.
LGTM and merged to trunk / 0.10.0.
Another minor question - do the corresponding windows `bat` scripts need to be updated as well?
